measured_by: time-horizon manipulation in a multi-armed bandit task
justification: “Manipulations that increase the value of exploration include: increasing the time horizon … In all of these cases, information seeking … increase when it is valuable to explore,” indicating that changes in time horizon within bandit tasks are used to gauge directed exploration.

“Directed exploration, but not random exploration, has been associated with several prefrontal structures and systems, including activity in … frontal theta oscillations [41],” showing frontal theta activity is used as a neural measure of directed exploration.

The article notes that “random exploration is associated with a sudden increase in neural variability and a loss of choice tuning in decision-making circuits in monkeys [47],” identifying circuit-level neural variability as the metric for random exploration.

“Norepinephrine levels and related measures, like pupil size [52,53], predict increased noise in behavior,” indicating that pupil diameter is employed as an indirect measure of central norepinephrine activity.

measured_by: behavioral choice variability (decision noise) in bandit tasks
justification: The authors state that “information seeking and behavioral variability increase when it is valuable to explore … providing strong evidence for the existence of both directed and random exploration in behavior,” using choice variability as a behavioral measure of random exploration.
